Adding first version of project mors

Adding a new project to OpenStack: project mors
http://github.com/platform9/pf9-mors

Mors is a useful tool for OpenStack based cloud used for dev, test or
lab setups. Typical usage in these scenarios include automatically or
manual creation of Instances for demo, test or experiments. In most
cases these Instances are forgotten and never deleted eating up valuable
resources.

Mors is a simple service that helps enforce a policy per Tenant or
Instance and automatically delete Instances after a specified duration.

Using this service can help administrator maintain a "LAB" more
efficiently. Currently project only support instance deletion and per
tenant level policy. Further work is planned to include glance images
and email notification with more complex policies around deletion of
those Instances/images, these include  powering off Instances, sending
notification and finally deleting them.

More details can be found here:

http://github.com/platform9/pf9-mors/README.md
and associated docs directory.

http://launchpad.net/mors

The project configuration is minimal. Trying to start
with minimal configuration to make sure basic git repo
import is working. It will certainly follow by few more

subject: Support l3 networking in shared vlan network
commit_message:
Support l3 networking in shared vlan network

1. What is the problem
Shared vlan type driver has been merged, so we can run two VMs in
the same network but across two pods. However if we attach a network
to the router, the tricircle plugin still check if the network is
bound to one AZ, so one network cannot cross different pods if we
are going to attach it to a router.

2. What is the solution to the problem
The reason we require network to be bound to AZ is that when the
network is attaching the one router, we know where to create the
bottom network resources. To support l3 networking in shared vlan
network, we need to remove this restriction.

In the previous patches[1, 2], we have already move bottom router
setup to an asynchronouse job, so we just remove the AZ restriction
and make the tricircle plugin and the nova_apigw to use the job.

Floating ip association and disassociation are also moved to bottom
router setup job.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
   to realize the solution
Now network can be attached to a router without specifying AZ, so
l3 networking can work with across-pod network.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/343568/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/345863/

subject: Deprecate Template.validate_resource_key_type()
commit_message:
Deprecate Template.validate_resource_key_type()

This is a utility function for validating the types of the various fields
in a resource definition during the validation phase, prior to creating the
ResourceDefinition object, that was added in
3f16eebd06bc964975b47496a6a1ef844986edfa.

Not only does this not belong in the public interface for all third-party
Template classes, but the implementation is nonsense. The verification code
must call it with a hard-coded key from the list of allowed keys along with
the allowed types for that value, and the method checks that the key is in
the list of allowed keys. (Surprise! It always is.) Meanwhile the keys
passed by the user are not checked for invalid values.

Fortunately the validity of the data passed by the user is checked
elsewhere as a side-effect of converting the resource definitions from HOT
to cfn, so we haven't been allowing bogus HOT templates since Kilo.
In the cfn-style templates we have never checked for invalid keys in the
resource definitions (and thus we can't really start), so the current
implementation was accidentally correct.

Since this is part of the public third-party interface we can't fix it
immediately. Instead, deprecate it and override it with a sane
implementation in the common parent class of HOT and CFN templates that was
added to hold such things. We'll remove it entirely from the public
interface later.

subject: Allow concurrent schedule() to run on HA routers
commit_message:
Allow concurrent schedule() to run on HA routers

Changeset I22ff5a5a74527366da8f82982232d4e70e455570 introduces a new
status for routers, ALLOCATING, which was intended to not inform l3
agents about HA routers that are currently being handled by a server
(either allocating resources for, or scheduling a router). This
approached turned out to have a few downsides, mainly the fact that a
router could be "locked" in the ALLOCATING state (see bug report for
details).

Instead, we're taking a different approach: a new counting index will be
added to the L3HARouterAgentPortBinding table that will help us keep
track of the amount of port bindings that are currently created (or
being created concurrently) for a HA router. This will help ensure that
a HA router will not be over-scheduled (will be scheduled to more l3
agents than allowed). An alternative approach for this is a
post-creation loop that checks if there are too many ports, and if there
are, delete the ports and back-off for some exponential amount of time.
This approach seemed better since we can be "forgiving" - as long as we
have the exact amount of ports, we're happy.

A second change that is made in this patch is the assignment of an
L3HARouterAgentPortBinding to an agent. Before, this patch, if more than
one worker has tried to create such a binding and it would already
exist, the error would be ignored. Instead, we'll take this as a sign to
make the server stop scheduling. That is, if 2 servers are trying to
schedule a HA router to the same agent, the second one that will try to
commit the transaction will know that he's too late and will stop the
scheduling attempts.

Lastly, this patch removes the unneeded return value from
auto_schedule_routers (and other functions invoked by it) and modifies
tests to check if that function actually worked by checking actual
router-to-agent bindings.

subject: Mark an HA router as ALLOCATING before deletion
commit_message:
Mark an HA router as ALLOCATING before deletion

Such a mark is required since when calling a router's delete_router,
some HA resources might be automatically cleaned up as well (thanks to
[1]). In this case, during a time where the resources are concurrently
deleted but before the router has been completely deleted, there exists
a state of inconsistency in the database (a HA router without all its
resources). This change proposes that when a router is to be deleted it
will be marked as ALLOCATING. This will allow future patches to depend
on this marking to detect if an action is inconsistent because of an
actual error or if it's simply in the middle of some
allocation/deallocation.

subject: Add new status DOWN for routers
commit_message:
Add new status DOWN for routers

A router may be stuck in the ALLOCATING state in some scenarios (as
described in the bug report, most obvious one is "handling
neutron-server crashed before re-setting the router to ACTIVE"). In
this case, the admin must do a series of router-update commands to fix
this issue (bringing the router down with --admin-state-up=False, then
removing the ha status and re-setting it when --ha=False and --ha=True,
and finally bringing it back up again with --admin-state-up=True).

These steps are not intuitive and the proposed change adds a new status,
"DOWN", which will be used when a router's admin_state_up attribute is
False. This will allow the user to skip the 2 steps regarding the HA
attribute of the router, and merely bring it down and back up.

Related-Bug: #1609738
Change-Id: I8784b6a499d7828d1cbcd701d91fa87477a764d8

subject: Re-schedule HA router on admin_state_up=True
commit_message:
Re-schedule HA router on admin_state_up=True

The current state of the code is that an HA router is scheduled to the
agents when the HA attribute of the router changes to True. This is
problematic since I22ff5a5a74527366da8f82982232d4e70e455570 introduces a
new state, ALLOCATING, for a router, and on the edge case where the
handling neutron-server crashes before changing the status of the router
to ACTIVE, an HA router may be stuck in the ALLOCATING state and it
won't get serviced by agents at all. Worse yet, this can be accompanied
by missing HA resources ("What? I have a vr_id for the router but no HA
ports have been allocated?? :<")

The manual fix for this is the non-intuitive guideline in which a router
should be brought down (--admin-state-up=False), its HAness should be
re-set (--ha=False followed by --ha=True) and then brought back up
(--admin-state-up=True). The gist of it is that the 2 steps involving
the HAness of the router are the ones that schedule/unschedule an HA
router from the agents, along with re-creating any resources that may be
missing.

Since the steps are rather not intuitive, this patch proposes skipping
the 2 steps of re-setting the HA attribute, allowing the user to fix the
bad state caused by merely bringing the router down and up again.

Closes-Bug: #1609738
Change-Id: I7a40eb0969a66153b17e2d3cae944fcbde5ab36b

subject: Add create_all and delete_all for AllocationList
commit_message:
Add create_all and delete_all for AllocationList

This is the object side of creating and deleting allocations in the
placement service.

create_all() checks that the inventory records involved in the
allocations requested do not have their capacities exceeded. If no
inventory capacities are exceeded, allocation records are written to the
database. Afterwards, the resource provider generation for each resource
provider involved in the allocation transaction has its generation
incremented. If another threads has concurrently updated either the
inventory or the usage of resources, this generation increment will
raise ConcurrentUpdateDetected, allowing callers to retry. This patch
does not yet implement this retry, which should be fine for the time
being considering that nothing yet calls POST /allocations.

Partially-Implements: blueprint generic-resource-pools

Co-Authored-By: Jay Pipes <jaypipes@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ed Leafe <ed@leafe.com>

Add binding_index to RouterL3AgentBinding

The patch proposes adding a new binding_index to the
RouterL3AgentBinding table, with an additional Unique Constraint that
enforces a single <router_id, binding_id> per router. This goes a long
way into fixing 2 issues:

1. When scheduling a non-HA router, we only use binding_index=1. This
   means that only a single row containing that router_id can be
   committed into the database. This in fact prevents over-scheduling of
   non-HA routers. Note that for the HA router case, the binding_index

   to agents using the RouterL3AgentBinding, while postponing the
   creation of L3HARouterAgentPortBinding objects for the agents until

subject: Create/update vNICs properly on Plug
commit_message:
Create/update vNICs properly on Plug

When deciding whether to "re-treat" or create a VIF, the PlugVifs Task
was only looking for CNAs with the matching MAC address.  With SR-IOV
VNIC, the VIF's MAC lives on the VNIC, not the CNA.

This change set detects whether a VIF is a VNIC; and if so, looks for a
matching VNIC rather than a matching CNA.

This change set also fixes a regression whereby PlugMgmtVif was only
looking in the list of pre-existing CNAs to see whether the management
VIF is already plugged.  We now also keep track of which CNAs we create
during PlugVifs and pass them along.  For efficiency, if we never look
up the existing CNAs, we pass None through, and PlugMgmtVifs looks up
the CNAs afresh.

subject: Sync Security Groups and SG Rules before other resources
commit_message:
Sync Security Groups and SG Rules before other resources

Neutron validates that a default security group is available (if not, it creates
one) before creating other resources. Currently, networking_odl during full sync,
pushes other resources before sync'ing security_groups/sg_rules.

ACL Service in ODL Controller would look at port[security_group] and would try to
apply the corresponding ACL flows on the VM ports. But since, SG/SG_rules are
sync'ed later, the first attempt in ACL service to program the flows returns a
WARNING saying that "ACL is empty". However, subsequently when SG/SG_rules are
sync'ed the necessary ACL flows are applied on the VM ports. This patch attempts
to optimize this by sync'ing the SG/SG_Rules prior to sync'ing the other resources

subject: rt: ensure resource provider records exist from RT
commit_message:
rt: ensure resource provider records exist from RT

This patch adds functionality to the scheduler "report client" to ensure
that the client calls the placement API to create a resource provider
record for the local compute host managed by the Nova resource tracker.

The report client keeps a cache of resource provider objects, keyed by
resource provider UUID and constructed from the results of placement
REST API calls to get information about a resource provider. If a
resource provider matching a UUID was not found in the placement REST
API, the report client automatically creates the resource provider
record via the placement REST API. These resource provider objects will
be used in followup patches that add creation of inventory and
allocation records to the scheduler report client.

Included in this patch is a new [placement] nova.conf configuration
section with a single os_region_name configuration option that allows
Nova to grab the placement API endpoint URL for the particular OpenStack
region that it is in. We do not support endpoint URL overrides for the
placement API service. We only use the Keystone service catalog for
finding the endpoint for the placement service. We intentionally modeled
the determination of the placement endpoint URL after similar code that
determines the volume endpoint URL in /nova/volume/cinder.py.

This redoes the placement API using keystone session, and stubs out
where we can do more reasonable handling of errors. This works if we
fill out the right credentials in the placement section of the config
file.

Co-Authored-By: Sean Dague <sean@dague.net>

subject: rbd_utils: wrap blocking calls in tpool.Proxy()
commit_message:
rbd_utils: wrap blocking calls in tpool.Proxy()

librbd is a Python binding around a C library, which is not aware of
eventlet - all the calls to the functions from this library will block
the whole nova-compute process for duration of a call. To make sure
nova-compute remains responsive we need to wrap all the calls in
tpool.Proxy() eventlet helper, that switches the execution context
back to the event loop, while the call is executed in a native OS
thread from a pool.

Prefer tpool.Proxy() to tpool.execute() here as the former allows for
wrapping objects and automatically executes all the method calls in
native OS threads, while the latter needs to be applied to each
method call in the code repeatedly.

Existing calls are modified for the sake of consistency.

Closes-Bug: #1607461

Change-Id: I743ab372332eb656258a476ae91f5e8fd2cbdc99

subject: Allow any data to be passed to yaql function
commit_message:
Allow any data to be passed to yaql function

There's no reason whatsoever that we can't pass data of any type, not
just dicts, to YAQL. It happily accepts lists, strings, ints, &c. Even
if it did not, we are actually passing a dict with a key named 'data'
that contains the actual data, so the data passed to YAQL is always a
dict. There's even less reason to restrict the contents of that first
key to also be a dict.

Since Newton will be the first release to include the yaql function, we
can relax the type checking now without creating any backward
compatibility issues.

This change does that and also simplifies the implementation of the Yaql
function class and stops it from doing dodgy things like overwriting the
expression with its resolved value.

Change-Id: Ia2c699f965c7fb59f74cc36fb1e14200dbbf7e74
